bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Grace T. Hallock, September 13, 1940

div1.p: Hench supplies details and references on the yellow fever experiments, correcting errors in the film strip Hallock prepared for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Grace T. Hallock, September 13, 1940

opener.dateline:
September 13, 1940 Miss Grace T. Hallock
Welfare Division
Metropolitan Life Insurance Co.
New York City

div1.p:
I hope indeed that my rather informal comments to Dr. Armstrong
concerning the historical accuracy of your pamphlet “Health Forces-Walter Reed”
did not disturb you. I really did not mean to criticize this pamphlet in any way. I
merely made my comments as a point of interest, and I am answering your letter, I can
assure you, in the most friendly spirit and without any critical views. However, because
we are both interested in this history of Walter Reed's experiments, may I make the
following comments.

Unfortunately, you entirely misunderstood which photograph I was referring
to when I mentioned a photograph showing a river between the Infected Mosquito Building
and the Infected Clothing Building, with mountains in the background. It was not the one
on page 15 of the pamphlet. I of course recognize that, as I not only have the Kelly
photographs, but also other photographs which I have got from the Army Medical Museum and
from survivors of the experiments. The photograph I refer to is the twenty-first photo-
graph in your film strip, placed between the picture of Lazear and the picture of Kissinger.
It is the one entitled “Camp Lazear in Cuba was constructed for control experiments”.
At my request, Dr. Armstrong kindly sent me an enlarged print of this particular picture.
In the film which he sent me, this particular picture is printed so that the background is
rather faint and one can't see the mountains, but in the enlarged print they are very clear,
and the river is unmistakable. Please do not misunderstand me. This is not particularly
important nor is it essential to have the diagrams on page 21 of your pamphlet absolutely
correct. After all, your pamphlet is for teaching purposes. As I mentioned in my letter
to Dr. Armstrong, so far as I can find out, the events pictured in Figures 1 and 3 on
page 21 never occurred. I have Senate Document 822, and have been over it so thoroughly
that I have it almost memorized. I of course knew of the Gorgas version on page 243
but since these incidents, as pictured in Figures 1 and 3, are not mentioned in any of the
official records of Reed, Carroll or others, nor in the informal records or papers of
Agramonte, one must conclude that Gorgas was taking slight liberties with the truth,
and was “clarifying the experiments” in his own mind. On pages 10, 86, and 100 of Senate
Document 822, it mentions two controls only being on Side A. It is true that Reed, on
page 99, mentions two controls and one other non-immune. That is why you have three
figures in the left box, but as I say, on the very next page (page 100) Reed says that the
two controls continued to sleep in that room at night. The other non-immune happens to
have been Dr. Reed himself. Apparently, he merely entered the room briefly for the purpose
of observing Moran being bitten. This data I found in a most detailed and interesting
article by Agramonte in the Scientific Monthly for December, 1915, which in many ways
gives dates and details much more clearly than in the official publications. When I
visited his daughter this Spring in Havana, and had the opportunity of looking over his
notes or memoranda, there was such evidence of meticulous accuracy in his notes that one
Miss Grace T. Hallock
- 2 -
September 13, 1940
cannot doubt his data. Why do you accept Gorgas' version and insert Figures 1 and 3,
but do not accept him in the other matters? Certainly, Reed's version should be con-
sidered the official and correct one, and at no place does he mention data which one
could use as the basis of Figures 1 and 3. On page 100 of the Senate Document, Reed
says, “The building was then closed except for the occupancy of the two non-immunes.”
As far as I can see, the only other man bitten in the mosquito side of the Infected
Mosquito Building was Jerregan. Thereafter (as Reed says on the bottom of page 100)
the volunteers were bitten in the separate annex of this Infected Mosquito Building;
that is, the separate room in which the mosquitoes were raised, quite apart from the
room occupied by Moran. In Agramonte's Scientific Monthly article, you will see the
diagram of this room in relation to the rest of the building, and this will explain the
curious shape of the building, as shown on page 17 of your pamphlet.

You say that you have visited the site of Camp Lazear yourself. I shall
be most interested to know when this was and where you found the camp site. The Cuban
government now has the supposed site marked with a temporary memorial which consists of
a tree surrounded by a small, low, wooden fence, and a large tin sign. This is right
behind the present Military City and within sixty-five feet of a railroad track. It is
right behind the Military Hospital on the Military City grounds which occupy the former
site of Camp Columbia. Is this where you saw the camp site? Unfortunately, this is not
the true camp site. Local tradition is mistaken and this actually was the site of the
temporary tent hospital where the patients who developed yellow fever at Camp Lazear,
a mile away, were immediately brought for the care of the doctors stationed at Camp
Columbia. Mr. Moran and I re-located the true site of the camp and had long conversations
with Senora Rojas, the widow of the man who loaned the camp to Reed and Agramonte, and
you will note in the Scientific Monthly article that Agramonte especially states that
Camp Lazear was on the San Jose farm, a mile from Camp Columbia. The present false camp
is much too near.

I have been trying to find Mrs. Reed's address, but have been unable
to do so. Should you find her address I shall be indeed delighted to have it. [Permit
me to send you a photograph of a model of Camp Columbia, made by a Cuban in 1900. The
model is now in the Military Barracks at Carliale, Pa. The photograph is from the Army
Medical Museum and shows the railroad track. General Kean remembers this track and
bridge, and the tents which formed the basis of the false identification of Camp Lazear
were apparently right across from this small bridge.]

Would you kindly send me a dozen copies of your pamphlet “Health Heroes”?
I am corresponding with a number of survivors and know they will be delighted to have
copies.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
